description: TREC-IS Incident Tweet Routing (High-Level) Information Types. Version four, Task 1, created for the 2020 edition of the track.

informationTypes.desc: The user is asking people to donate goods/money
The user is asking people to leave an area or go to another area
The user is asking people to volunteer to help the response effort
The  author is providing some advice to the public
The post contains contextual information that can help understand the event, but is not about the event itself.
Users are discussing the event
The post is un-related to the event or contains no information.
The post is expressing some sentiment about the event
A report of the clean up after the event
The user is reporting a potential problem that may cause future loss of life or damage
The user is relating some facts, typically numerical
The user is giving an eye-witness account
Reporting which hashtags correspond to each event
The post contains information about the user or observation location
The user is sharing images or video
The post is a news report providing/linking to current/continious coverage of the event
The user is reporting a new occurence that public safety officers need to respond to.
An official report by a government or public safety representative
A report of the original event occuring. This was in effect the 'Other-KnownAlready' category from 2018.
The user is reporting that they or someone else is providing a service
The user is reporting a information that they recieved from someone else
The user is providing a weather report (current or forcast)
The user is asking for a particular service or physical good.
The user is requesting information
The user is requesting a rescue (for themselves or others)

audienceTypes.desc: This tweet does not have a clear intended audience
This tweet provides information about what is happening at the community level or information for individuals directly impacted by the event
This tweet provides general information about the event, including statistics, outlook, or other information intended for those not directly impacted by the hazard

imageTypes.desc: This tweet provides general information about the event, including statistics, outlook, or other information intended for those not directly impacted by the hazard
An image appears taken from a satellite
A weather forecast, either graphic or satellite projection
Textual graphic with information or statistics about the event
A photograph of some weather phenomenon, e.g., a storm, tornado, wildfire, etc. This category is separate from weather forecasts
Photograph showing victims of or someone who was directly impacted by the crisis
Photograph of damage of infrastructure, homes, vehicles, landscape, or similar
Photograph shows a group of people
Photograph of recovery efforts, such as a rescue operation, donations, or volunteering efforts
Screenshot taken from a phone, computer, or video

authorTypes.desc: Whether knowing the author was informative
account represents media outlets such as local news affiliates, newspapers, or national/global news organizations
account represents a local, regional, or federal governmental agency
account represents a corporations, NGO, or community organization
account represents a politician, elected/appointed official, one who hold public office, or spokesperson for a governmental agency
account appears to belong to an individual who otherwise does not hold some position of authority
account and its content appears to be populated by some sort of automated feed (e.g., Weather warning bots)
